newsitem.title: NETHERLANDS: Rabobank hidden reserves Dfl 3.5 bln.
newsitem.headline: Rabobank hidden reserves Dfl 3.5 bln.

text.p: Dutch co-operative bank Rabobank Nederland said on Wednesday it had hidden reserves of almost 3.5 billion guilders at December 31.
The unlisted bank was revealing the size of its provision for general contingencies, designated by the Dutch acronym VAR, for the first time.
Dutch banks have been ordered to unveil their VAR, or hidden reserves, by the year 2000 to comply with changes to European Union rules.
They will shift these reserves into a new open fund, which carries the acronym FAR, and into general reserves.
The new FAR fund is designed for unexpected exceptional loan losses, potential claims and law suits and, under normal circumstances, no deductions will be made from this fund.
Actual loan losses, which were previously covered by additions to the VAR fund, will from 1997 by deducted directly from each banks' profit and loss account.
Analysts expect a once-off rise in bank profits as a result of these changes because they will cut provisions for loan losses, having overprovided for such losses in the past.
